"I should have fed him in time..."The Whispered World is one of Daedalic Entertaintment's adventure titles, and promises a lot as it starts, yet fails to keep any of those promises throughout the game itself. I wasn't expecting an experience as grand as Memoria, but at least hoping for the kind of quality in story and display of beauty as we encountered in Chains of Satinav. What I encountered, was beautiful potential spent badly on a sad little clown.The storybook opens and a worn-out narrator warns us that this will be the last story that he'll be telling ever. Then, we meet Sadwick: the sad little clown. He is a misanthropic, pessimistic and annoying little boy who runs a circus alongside his brother Ben and his grandfather. One morning, Sadwick jumps down from his bed, shaken and terrified of a nightmare that indicates the world is ending. Oh, wait! According to a messenger of the King that Sadwick will be meeting in the forest, the world IS ending for reasons that we are not aware yet. The messenger Bobby advices Sadwick to seek Shana, a mythical oracle that resides in the forest who can interpret Sadwick's dream. With a quest at hand, Sadwick's journey towards the unknown starts...I'll start with my most basic complaint: the game doesn't work properly! There is an odd clicking bug that starts the minute you run the game, and keeps haunting you until the very end. You have to click on something 5-6 times for the game to acknowledge that you are clicking on it. It is hellishly annoying for a POINT AND CLICK adventure game. The puzzles themselves are obscure and random enough, and you never know whether you're trying the wrong item combination, or just game doesn't register your clicking. On that manner, it is impossible to finish the game without divine persistency and a walkthrough.The background art and the interface music are pretty, as if taken from a German folktale. But characters and the style of art chosen to illustrate them are off putting. Animations are broken half the time, and the lip synch with the audio is non-existent. It takes forever for Sadwick to walk with the given animation. It seems all these issues are commonly known for the "Special Edition" and no solution has been offered for now.As a character, our protagonist Sadwick is incredibly annoying and lacks personal depth. His voice is off putting - and drives you insane since we'll be with him only until the end of game. There is no logical correlation between story progression and any kind of visible personal growth either. Nothing justifies his choices, and nothing explains them either. There is also no observable reason to Sadwick's endless vailing or suffocating pessimism to begin with. Sadwick is a character which is impossible to empathize with. He is basically shallow.As for Spot's - Sadwick's victimized caterpillar - transformations and the way that Sadwick treats him, I found it to be disgusting. Poor little thing is literally tortured to even achieve given transformations! He is sliced, pressed and burned numerous times without even a single complain! He is even nailed to a rack as part of a puzzle nearing the end of the game. If I were to be Spot, I'd tell Sadwick: "♥♥♥♥ you! ♥♥♥♥ you for being a selfish and miserable fool! ♥♥♥♥ you for putting me through all these ordeals! You don't deserve neither my loyalty nor my affection! I'm done with you, Sadwick! Go play the part of the sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on someone else! ♥♥♥♥ you!” Whew, sorry. I gotta get that off my chest.I definitely don't recommend this game, for its broken controls, its annoying protagonist, its sick sense of humor, and definitely for its dramatized yet shallow ending. Sorry, guys and gals. I finished this game through sheer willpower and an obsession for completing a story that I started. I love the next Daedalic adventure just as you do, but this one doesn't worth it.Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												I found this to be a very charming point-and-click adventure game.  The focus of the story is on a depressive child clown by the name of Sadwick, who departs from his family circus to avert the end of the world from coming to pass.The story is more of a whimsical one, but the game is not a comedy and does take itself seriously.  You get a nice amount of character growth from Sadwick and the course of the story has you meet new and interesting characters in each scene along the way.  The amount of depth to each character you meet was pleasantly surprising, and at least a few really made for some happy smile-inducing moments and the German voice acting is quite expressive (see my note below) .  The environments are very beautifully drawn and in-game animations are very good too.  There are some cutscenes which have less polish, looking maybe more like a 90's cartoon but overall did not detract from the experience for me.  The music is quite good, even if some of the tracks are re-used a few too many times.Game ran just fine, but doesn't alt-tab too well.  Saving, mouse controls, the GUI are all perfectly fine.  The game has no failstates, and you can hold Spacebar to highlight interactables.  This game does have a fair few number of puzzles that are not easy to intuit the solutions for, so you will likely have to resort to a guide more often than you'd like.  This is par for the course in adventure games, although the par is a bit high in this game.I also wanted to address a few complaints I saw a lot in other people's reviews.Performance : Many users complained of the game failing to launch, launching to a black screen, or crashing.  I never once had any such issue.  I hope others who do are able to resolve theirs.Sadwick's walking speed : Some users complained that Sadwick walks too slow.  In most adventure games you can double-click on screen transitions to automatically trigger them.  You can do that in this game too, so its possible those users did not know.  Sadwick walks at a fine pace otherwise, no scene is especially large bar one and even then the transitions in that area are numerous.Voice acting : I heard that the English dub VA for Sadwick is unbearable and whiny.  Given his personality in the game I could see why this might be, so I used the original German voice acting and enjoyed it thoroughly.  I have no problems with using the German VA.Broken audio : Some users comment that audio seems to cut off abruptly at the end of some spoken lines.  I cannot comment on the English audio, but this is sometimes noticeable in the German audio. I did not find it common enough nor disruptive enough to say it was any significant detriment, although the developers should fix it if so.Controls : Some users complain the game fails to register mouse clicks.  I never had this happen, but you do have to hold down the mouse button to open the small interaction menu.Story : Some people just don't like the premise or character personality, or how the game ends.  That's fine, its just down to taste.  I enjoyed it, others will not.All in all, I would recommend it.  I very much enjoyed myself.  About 10-12 hrs playtime.

												The Whispered World falls into the realm of zany adventure games, complete with a morose, unlovable schlub for a protagonist.  Unfortunately, zany and surreal adventures invariably involve a certain amount of "try everything on everything" to progress, and this runs afoul of the crappy interface.Frequently, The Whispered World fails to register a mouse click, so you never know, when trying an object on another, or an object on part of the environment, if it truly did nothing, or if the game simply didn't notice your attempt.  Sometimes it takes four or five clicks to get the game to respond.  After the third time that I gave up on a puzzle, checked a walkthrough, and discovered that the correct solution was, in fact, one of the first things I had tried, except that the game hadn't deigned to notice at the time, I gave the whole thing up as a bad exercise in frustration.If you're masochistic enough to endure this game, make a point of clicking several times when trying anything; hopefully one of the clicks will register.  The art, incidentally, is quite beautiful, it's simply a shame what aggravating hoops you must jump through to see it.(And, yes, my mouse works fine in all other applications, so I feel confident blaming the game engine for this non-responsiveness.)

												tl;dr: Some really fantastic artwork and an interesting world with fun secondary characters to explore. That aside, this game misses too many marks to be really good, and becomes almost a chore towards the end, mostly due to the old bane of point & clicks: illogical puzzles and rushed final chapters.It's a mostly melancholic story with great moments of bleak humour, one that promises to be interesting but loses steam along the way. There is some fun writing to be found in it (I do love me some Talking Rocks and any and all quips they feel like making are fine by me), but the story becomes weirdly convoluted in the last chapter. The world building is fascinating nonetheless, and along with the gorgeous art they are clearly the highlights of the experience. As for the english voice over, it has some bad moments but it's mostly alright. The hero's voice may take some getting used to though.For me the major let down is that too many of the puzzles are really unintuitive and illogical, and there is only that much drudgery I'm willing to accept in my play. I don't care if that was fine when Lucas Arts did it, it isn't fine now, especially not if you expect me to traverse multiple screens with a really slow character to try out totally random things that follow no internal logic whatsoever. It gets worse as the chapters progress, and by the last one you'll have too many moments of being hard pressed to figure out what to do next without immense patience or a walkthrough. Any guidance, even subtle indications, would have helped, but they are as lacking as any type of a hint system.On a positive note, if you were worried about bugs the "Special Edition" seems to have taken care of most of the previous problems. Just bear in mind that this is an older game so there are limited resolutions offered - expect black bars if you have a wide screen. High DPI displays will also need to disable display scaling to be able to play in fullscreen.So would I suggest it? Probably not. I'm usually a sucker for projects of love even if they end up being lovable trainwrecks, and this game oozes love for its unlikely world-weary child hero and its odd world. But halfway through it just stopped being fun to actually play, there were one too many misses and not enough hits. While I don't regret the time I spent with it, I still can't recommend it and I'd suggest waiting for a steep discount if you decide to try it yourself.

												I have such mixed feelings about this game that I'm hard pressed on whether or not to recommend it.To start off with, the artwork is absolutely GORGEOUS and features traditionally animated cutscenes. The music is quite nice as well, though the voice acting is hit and miss. The characters themselves are quite vibrant and full of personality - we follow the journey of our would-be hero Sadwick, a down-on-his-luck circus clown with clinical depression, who discovers that he has been fated to... destroy the world. As you can imagine he rejects this prophesy, determined to instead save his world from crumbling to dust. Initially I found Sadwick's character to be annoying with how whiney he was about everything, but as I followed him and got to know him, I started to relate to his depression more and saw much of myself reflected in him. He really just needs a hug. As for the puzzles, they're fairly difficult and often frustrating and illogical. More than once I had to look up a guide.UNfortunately, despite how gorgeous this game is and how interesting I'd found the story, the direction the ending wound up taking I felt to be such a massive cop-out that I'm actually pretty angry. In retrospect it was pretty obvious, but it was such an extremely lazy and unimaginitive "plot twist" that it pretty much destroyed the rest of the game's magic. So, while everything else about the game is good and I would recommend it based off of that, the ending is just SO unsatisfying that I feel extremely conflicted to say yes.If you truly want this game, wait and get it on sale. Don't waste your money paying full price just to be slapped by the ending.

"This statue ain't moving. Pretty much like everything else in my life."One of my most favorite genres is point n' click and Daedalics are THE titans of point and clicks. I learn more about the characters if I explore everything. It takes me a while but I'm in no hurry. After all, that's how point and click should be played. No such thing as speed run. Everytime Daedalics tell a different story that makes me want to stay with characters longer. A pity every story has an end. The day will come when you'll have to bid farewell to your fictional friends. This time it's a story about Sadwick the sad clown and Spot the caterpillar - his handsome sidekick and best friend. Sadwick is a lovable character. He's a lovely satirist and a courageous boy. Complains about problems but still tries his best to do everything in his power and can't leave things undone. He's not your casual hero that likes making promises and then break them. He's more like an anti-hero that doesn't care about fame and glory. He just wants to fix the big end-of-the-world problem. The nightmare that he has been having turned out to be a good excuse to start exploring the world. He is very insecure and has anxiety problems so I can relate to him. I wish I were as brave as that kiddo.  Sadwick isn't as stupid and useless as his older brother Ben makes him feel. I've always wanted to punch that guy for bullying Sadwick. I could never forget about the awesome talking rock bros - Ralv and Yngo, that wanted to enslave the world  with a rock hard fist but sadly they couldn't do anything but lie about. Grandpa's underpants are more useful than arrogant Bobby the Chaski. I played it in english and I like Sadwick's voice. Not sure why people think he has an annoying voice. I think it's quite adorable.That game has a deep meaning and I would hate to ruin it with spoilers. I just wonder how many of us would like to preserve the world they've been living in without changing anything or whatsoever and for what price.

												The Whispered World is a beautiful game that stirs deep emotion and brings a good few laughs along with it, cleverly using satire without overdoing it and creating a depressed character that is 100% likable. Sadwick is amusing, adorable, and superbly written, displaying characteristics of those with depression accurately which allows people to relate to him easily. I have seen rather a few complaints about the voice acting, which personally I thought was brilliant. At no point did I cringe or find it unnatural, and I found that the tone to Sadwick's voice was perfect for his role and his personality. He has asthma, vertigo, depression and anxiety which he either comments on or is obvious throughout the game, giving a wide range of mental instabilities that people can relate to. The backgrounds and soundtrack are absolutely gorgeous, and the artwork you gain for finishing the game are a pleasure to look at and feel like a very worthy reward.The clicking sometimes doesn't respond and you have to double click or place items in a very specific place, but I found myself wanting to continue the game so much that by a few minutes in I really didn't care about the extra clicking sometimes required and even got used to it. The hotspot indicator is VERY useful in the game and you WILL have to use it in almost every screen, but again I just find the feature useful and it didn't bother me at all.Daedalic are masters at immersive point and click adventures, and this was just the beginning of their incredible games. Their gift for creating magical stories with interesting and likable characters sparkles in this game, and at the reduced price it is now, it's well worth the money.

SummaryThe Whispered World is a point & click adventure game made by Daedalic Entertainment. What most likely seemed like a good game on paper (a medieval fantasy setting and a basic mystery to build a story around, decent graphics, nice music and sound effects) turned out to be a sub par game due to its meager story, its lack of interesting characters, its awful voice acting and the fact that too many situations will have you searching for a walkthrough to look up the far-fetched or completely illogical solution.Story, humour and voice actingYou play as Sadwick, a child clown from a small family of travelling circus artists. Sadwick is plagued by ominous nightmares and he wants to find out more about them. So he's off to find an oracle who supposedly lives in the forest where the circus happened to make camp.Sadwick is a whiner. Plain and simple. In every conversation he will talk about how he feels sad and worthless, and complain that nobody likes him. Even after statements that don't call for whining, he does it anyway. For example, when clicking on a statue and he says "The statue won't move", he adds "Pretty much like everything else in my life". Even after basic statements to tell the player "I can't do that" he sometimes adds things like "I'm too stupid/clumsy/weak/worthless". This gets old very soon.The story and the dialogue aren't very captivating. Most of the conversations are repetitive and long-winded with little content. It didn't take long before I found myself skipping through most of it and just glimpsing the gist of the conversation from the subtitles that raced past. A second reason to skip through the dialogue is the terrible voice acting. Sadwick's voice is forced and annoying. Most of the other character's voices are annoying, too. The remaining voice acting is mediocre at best.The humour isn't funny at all. A senile grandpa who says 'compost' when he means 'compass'. Hilarious. Your character who misunderstands the messenger when he says 'the whispering stone' and repeats 'the blistering bone?' Side-splitting. If childish wordplay isn't your thing, don't worry. They included gags that require visualizing, too, for example:"That stone looks like a cow's behind"!Not far into the game things seem to take a turn for the better when an interesting and mysterious element is added to the story when some sparking electrical conduits appear out of nowhere in this medieval world, in our protagonist's trailer no less! But Sadwick says, and I quote: "I've decided to just ignore them" and that's that. You can't talk to the other characters about them and you can't examine them further. Seriously? This is the equivalent of looking out the window into your backyard, seeing a space ship landing there and thinking to yourself: "Ah well, I'll close the curtains and have a look what's on TV tonight".The ending is predictable and actually makes little sense when you think about it. But it's clear the developers didn't give the story a lot of thought so we shouldn't either, I guess.GameplayThe gameplay is a bit strange for a point & click game. A minor gripe is that you have to target stuff with the centre of a large mouse pointer. Even though it doesn't take long to get used to this, it keeps feeling clumsy throughout the whole game. More importantly, they turned The Whispered World into a 'point & hold game': a regular short mouse click only makes your character walk to an object, but to interact with it you need to hold the mouse button down for a second. The whole thing just feels counter-intuitive.You can press SPACE to highlight all the objects you can interact with. I read that a lot of people find this game hard because some of the puzzles are rather far-fetched, so I used this function a lot. I wanted to avoid 'pixel hunting' and getting stuck because I missed some small item in a corner somewhere. Sounds like a plan, right? Well, the first time I got stuck and looked up a walkthrough, it turned out I missed an item anyway. This item was hidden somewhere, in a corner so to speak, and it did not show when pressing SPACE. *Sigh* So use the highlight function, but don't count on it being foolproof.And, by the way, those people were right: at least a dozen of the solutions to problems in this game are far-fetched or just don't make any sense. After a few of those moments I pretty much gave up on playing this game without a walkthrough next to me. Which is a shame, because that takes a lot of the fun out of playing an adventure game.When you execute one of those impossible-to-guess solutions, Sadwick litterally says: "That's so crazy... I don't even know why I try." Seriously. No kidding.The developers even created an achievement for using a walkthrough! You get an achievement called 'Walkthrough user' for solving a puzzle without performing any wrong action, which is indeed only possible if you're following a walkthrough to the letter. There's another achievement that requires you to do a whole segment of the game perfectly, without making any error, so that's pretty much the same thing.Graphics and soundThe graphics are decent enough. The decors of this medieval fantasy world aren't breathtaking but they are easy on the eye. What I don't understand is why a 'special edition' release from the year 2014 has no widescreen support. Besides, the game was originally released in 2009 so it wasn't ancient to begin with. But unless you still have a 4:3 monitor, you will see a broad black bar on the left and right side of your screen. This isn't a matter of settings. Take a look at the screen shots on the store page: they have the black bars, too.Often, you hear no music at all. But when there is music playing, it's quite beautiful and atmospheric. I especially liked the music in the second chapter. The sound effects and the ambient sounds are very nice, too.Bugs and crashesThere are a few minor bugs in the game. Sometimes you hear or read a completely different line than intended. A few objects still have their German names. Like I said: minor bugs but signs of sloppiness nevertheless. I also experienced a couple of CTD's (crash to desktop) so save regularly.On Steam's extra featuresThe Whispered World has 7 trading cards. You'll get 4 while running the game.The Steam Achievements are uninspired. First, you have your classic, unmissable story-related achievements. Then there are a few missable achievements. I already talked about the two achievements that reward people who use a step-by-step walkthrough or at least a 100% achievement guide. Well, there is also an achievement for skipping all of the game's minigame puzzles. That's about the equivalent of giving a medal to wartime deserters, isn't it?The other missable achievements usually boil down to 'perform an optional action 10 times'. Each of those 10 times you'll have to sit through an animation or even an entire cutscene, so they're pretty boring achievements that you'll only get when you use an achievements guide.And then there is an achievement called 'Master of Disguise', which you get for clicking a few hundred times on some ingame buttons. Again. They already did the same thing in The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav with its 'Destroyer' and 'Healer' achievements.Steam Achievements can be a great thing when they add optional extra 'quests', challenges and depth to a game. I'm seriously starting to have my doubts about Daedalic Entertainment. Apparently they are convinced that 'click some buttons 500 times' is a challenge that adds more fun to playing a game, and that people should be rewarded for using a walkthrough and for skipping puzzles. I still have a few more games from the 'Daedalic Bundle' to go, so wish me better luck on my next pick...

And The Whispered World: Special Edition doesn't disappoint in the eyes of fans.I have to be honest with you, I've encountered none of the problems reported by the earlier reviewers. I don't know whether they have been patched or not by this time, but my experience in the game leads me to believe that they have been.In this game, we follow the journey of Sadwick, a want-to-be hero with clinical depression, who discovers that he has been fated to destroy the world. As you can imagine, he rejects this prophesy, determined instead to save the world from crumbling to dust. Sadwick is a clown in the fantastical realm of Silentia, where he travels with a circus featuring only his brother, his grandfather, and himself. His life consists only of menial chores, burping the alphabet for audiences, and playing the cannonball in the headlining human cannonball act. His brother despises him and his senile grandfather forgets he exists. So yeah, he's a pretty lonely and depressive character. The game is full of dark jokes like "This statue ain't moving. Pretty much like everything else in my life." which is pretty funny and emotional at the same time. You will find yourself asking a lot of times if you should cry of laughter or maybe of sadness. Also, Spot, the caterpillar, is his handsome sidekick and the only friend he has, but they are a great team together. The main character complains about a lot of problems but he tries to do everything in his power to don't leave things undone. He's not your casual hero that likes making promises and breaking them after. He doesn't care about fame and glory. He just wants to fix the big end of the world problem. The nightmares that he has been having turnes out to be a good excuse to start exploring the world in which he lives. So that's how his adventure begins.The world created by the developers is vibrant, creative and beautifully brought to life through the eyes of Sadwick. And while many complain that the ending was awful, the story really got into me and let me tell you that it will have a very emotional impact on you too. Like any Daedalic Entertainment game would do.Pros- The story is fantastic and quite emotional with an great impactful ending.- Absolutely stunning hand-drawn artwork!- Excellent soundtrack that should get you excited for the fantastical adventure that follows.- Over 10 hours of story-driven atmosphere!- Developer commentary on each and every screen in the game you can listen to, that offers great insights into the art direction, story, and puzzle design, with a few puzzle solutions spoiled. Or stories and memories from the development process if you are interested about how the game was done.Cons- No widescreen support even though it's special edition.- Many illogical and obtuse puzzles. A couple of puzzles make no sense until after you’ve figured them out by accident. So don't be ashamed, open a handy walkthrough for occasional use and enjoy the beautifully told and realized story!- Sadwick’s voice takes some time getting used to, and the voices are sometimes interrupted with a second before finishing the sentence.- Some of the dialogue and humor feel awkward.ConclusionSadwick is a lovable character. He's a lovely sarcastic and courageous boy with a bipolar side. Like any kid, he's confused about a lot of things, he's very insecure and has anxiety problems which will let many people relate to him. This game is a nice portal to our childhood and I'm sure you'll find yourself a lot of times in the main character. The story is suitable for just about everyone, so you can play it with your kid if you want to. In the end, how much you enjoy this game will be particularly subjective, depending on what you look for in an adventure game. If you’re willing to tolerate some ludicrous puzzles to enjoy a beautiful world with gorgeous, top notch art and music, you’ll find The Whispered World worthwhile.This review is a part of Steamified's Community Reviews program and the credit goes to both Steamified and Daedalic Entertainment for providing the key for review purposes.For similar Steamified Reviews and Giveaways, please visit http://www.steamified.com/. You're also welcome to join in the fun in our Steamified group.

												There are things to like about this game, but for me this would be a neutral review if it were possible.Back before the special edition was out I tried to play this game a few times. I’d never get past the first chapter because I didn’t want to have to use a guide. I found the main characters voice pretty annoying and I wasn’t really feeling at all connected with the character I would have to stick with for the entirety of the game. Despite that, the concept of the game sounded interesting and at the time I thought it was a well-loved classic of a game. With a closer look, maybe this wasn’t as popular as I initially thought.I started up the special edition, determined this time to finish. I have to say, I think this game would be impossible for anyone to finish without a guide. Some of the puzzles are a little nonsensical and it seems quite easy to miss clues as to what you’re supposed to be doing. There is a level of logic to what to do, but it was spread very thinly at times. I found this game a little frustrating regarding the puzzles. Admittedly at times I am pretty horrible at point and clicks, but I don’t think I have ever had such a hard time with one as I had with this one. I love Daedalic’s games and I definitely love their charm and style, but this one is probably the worst of theirs I have played so far (although, it should be taken into consideration that this was one of their first games and it is pretty old).I noticed in other reviews that people mentioned bugs and crashes. Fortunately for me I had no problems at all with that kind of thing. The game ran perfectly for me, as said above, I just wasn’t very good at it.It has to be said that the art in this game is absolutely amazing. The background scenery really are works of art and they have created a beautiful world here. It was also quite nice that they have added in an icon in the top left that you can press to hear developer commentary. Although spoken in German, it was nice reading it to see the personalities behind Daedalic a little more. You can definitely see where the humour and style comes from.The concept of the game and the story was enjoyable. I’m not sure it was great enough to say that it made up for my frustration just trying to get through the game, but it was still enjoyable. I grew to like the main character a little more and his cute little sidekick Spot. The game in general had an old-timey fantasy film feel about it. Like Labyrinth or The Never Ending Story. I quite liked that as you don’t really see much with that same feel to it these days.All in all it’s an okay game. I found it pretty difficult to get through but I wouldn’t say it was bad. It’s a fairly easy game to 100% as long as you save often to keep checkpoints and if you are a fan of the genre or the developers then you may as well give it a go and see how you get on.I don’t usually say this but for some reason with this game I am interested to know how other people got on with this game. Would you agree that this was a difficult one to get through without a guide or am I really just that bad at point and clicks?TL;DR : It’s okay, but that’s as far as I could say. I would rate this neutrally if it were possible. The art is amazing, the main character took some coming around to, the puzzles are a little nonsensical and it definitely wasn’t my favourite point and click, but it ran perfectly for me despite other reviewers saying they had problems with bugs and crashes.

Short version: 79%An interesting point ‘n’ click adventure game with a bunch of unique ideas and almost painfully broken controls. Whispered World is probably not the greatest game released by Daedalic Entertainment, but if you like stories which set up everything for the last five minutes, then it’s a must-have.Long version:The Whispered World is an interesting specimen. At first it seems like a usual old-style point ‘n’ click adventure, where the plot is large suppressed by the depressingly pessimistic attitude of the protagonist. On top of that, the story introduces a lot of seemingly unconnected and strange elements at every turn, which usually don’t lead anywhere in particular. Until you get to the very end and realise Whispered World is like movies such as Usual Suspects or Sixth Sense: everything was just a very long setup for the final huge twist.Is it a good twist at least? It’s hard to tell. To some degree it’s predictable and clichéd. On the other hand it is a bittersweet ending that fits the overall tone.The seemingly unconnected aspects of the plot translate into a fairly challenging puzzle system, where the role of items and hotspots are not always (or always not) obvious. This leads to a fair share of trial and error scenarios, especially in the last third the story, where everything gets increasingly surreal.From a technical standpoint, the game has a few problems, like disturbingly choppy animations and sluggish, somewhat unresponsive controls. Many people also suffer from audio sync problems. These shortcomings won’t make it unplayable, but they may result in some unneeded frustration that could have been averted with a little more care.

												Before I begin in earnest, I'll give this caveat: It is absolutely imperative that you turn off the audio for the dialogue in this game. The person they employed to voice the protagonist delivers, bar none, the absolute worst performance I have ever experienced in a game within this or any other genre. It's not just a case of it being weird or unconvincing (though make no mistake - it is both weird and unconvincing) - it's a case of it actually inducing physical pain via headaches. It is whiny, grating, nasal, and draws out every vowel for about twice as long as it should. It is Woody Allen mach 10. It is so unbelievably terrible that it took me four years between buying the game when it first came out and finishing it today, as in my first play session I found Sadwick's voice so utterly loathsome that I uninstalled the game and forgot it even existed until the Special Edition popped up in my library out of leftfield.So, with that said, is the game worth playing? The answer to this question is a heavily qualified 'yes'. The hype that built up around The Whispered World in the lead-up to its release was, in my estimation, completely unmerited, but it's a good enough game.Much has been made of the lack of logic in the game's puzzles, though in my experience only a half dozen or so had a 'How in God's name did they expect me to know that?' solution. While moments like this are infuriating and speak to anachronistic game design, if you're prepared to just consult a walkthrough when you're hopelessly stuck, attribute the momentary catapults into the sky of stupidity to infrequent acid flashbacks on the designer's behalf, and then just carry on resituated on our beloved terra firma, they're not intolerable. In my estimation most of the puzzles are actually amongst the better within the genre, but some may just have a single step which is complete nonsense, or, worse yet, actively go against what Sadwick intimates you should do with an object in his 'hint' dialogue.Divorced from the godawful voice acting, the writing is actually pretty decent and on a few, rare occasions genuinely funny. The plot employs a stock standard three act structure (albeit spread over four): get quest, get delayed, complete quest. It brings nothing new to the table in this respect, but it's serviceable.My primary criticism of The Whispered World is the world itself. The hand drawn art is certainly pretty, if somewhat lacking in vibrancy, but the world itself is just dead. It's quiet, depopulated, and dull. The Asgil, which are meant to be an impossibly fearsome threat to everything good, are two guys. No more. Two guys - the boss and the bumbling underling. A halfway prepared opposition could take these guys out with slingshots and peas. That would be if the world's regular inhabitants who might form this opposition weren't similarly scarce. Most acts introduce no more than three new characters, whom you never really need to speak to more than twice (albeit at some considerable, and arguably unnecessary length). I didn't really care for the story of this depressive clown prophesied to destroy the world, because it was a world I found impossible to become invested in. It's not so much a world as a series of tableauxs, connected with varying degrees of success. My sole motivation to persevere was to find the next puzzle. And as an addendum, I also found the ending to be a self-consciously sentimental attempt to lend this rather small and unambitious story an unearned sense of epic, emotional gravitas. It's not signposted in any way, and really just feels cheap, but I guess your mileage may vary on this.If you're a hardcore adventure game enthusiast, by all means give TWW a shot, but that's really the only audience that would truly enjoy this game, because the state of the genre over the past decade or two has turned us into a rather forgiving lot. I'd advise anyone else to steer well clear.

												I never got around to playing this game after I got it some while ago. That changed with the release of the Special Edition, and I finally got to accompany Sadwick on his adventure to save/destroy the world. Seeing that I never played the regular edition I can not compare the two, but the special edition seems to add very little. Mostly you have the option to listen to commentaries in every scene by the creators of this game. Graphic is supposed to be upgraded and you now get achievements. I don't know if there is anything more than that. Anyhow, nice to get an updated version now before the release of the next game in the series.The game itself is beautifully created in a cartoonish and colorful world, with equally colorful characters. The artwork is magnificent. It is as expected a point & click adventure game of the traditional sort. Familiar to anyone who is familiar with other Daedelic games, and other similar game developers.The biggest plus of this game is its story. It is interesting and engaging all the way through with a finish that rivals most great game finishes. All characters are voiced and there is a narrator as well. The narrator does a good job, but some of the other voice actors leaves a lot to be desired. The voice of the protagonist, Sadwick, sounds like when Adam Sandler speaks childish somewhat crossed with Cartman from South Park. In other words it can be quite annoying at times. It doesn't help when Sadwick is a very depressed character that is pessimistic about just about everything. Now, there is an underlying reason for this, and one seems to get used to the voice eventually. There are other poor efforts of voice acting too, but nothing that gets on your nerves. It's by no means all bad. Some characters are voiced quite well, especially some of the "evil" ones.(Note: I have only played the English version and can not comment on voice-overs in other languages)What is probably more annoying is the fact that the voice overs seems to go straight from one into the other with no space/break between them. Badly coreographed in other words. It even has a few lines broken off too early and even completely which is really poor. Hopefully they will come up with a fix for that.I also found the pointer/clicking to be quite unresponsive at times. I had to try another game to check if it was my mouse going bad or if it was in fact the game, and unfortunately/luckily it was the game. The controls was a bit clunky in the first place, but the unresponsiveness certainly didn't help.Achievements is a nice new addition, but also this seemed to be a bit bugged. There was a couple I should have gotten but never got. I'm not an achievement horder, so to me it doesn't matter much, but if this is something that is important to you it doesn't seem to work correctly. Probably an easy fix that they hopefully will deal with quickly enough.Don't let the negativity scare you off though. I still recommend this game for any fan of point & click adventures and anyone who appreciate a great story. The bugs/issues are easily overlooked if you are not to caught up in details. In fact the story itself is worth your money and time to play through this game. It also helps that it is from Daedelic, who is one of the companies who has kept this genre alive through hard times. And they have done so with lots of great titles. They deserve some support from us who appreciate games like this. Throw some money at them ;o).6/10

												I've played quite a few Casual Games in my time ranging from Adventure to Hidden Object to Match 3, and I must say, the Whispered World Special Edition, is one of the best I have played in a long time!!WARNING! REVIEW MIGHT CONTAIN SLIGHT SPOILERS, Nothing major though!!The game starts out with Sadwick, a 12 Year old depressed clown in a Fantasy World known as Silentia. He is asleep in a moving trailer and keeps having the same nightmare. The world is collapsing and there is a Blue Moon that keeps haunting Sadwick. When he wakes up from his nightmare, we are introduced to the action and get to start playing!GAMEPLAY & CONTROLS -This game is a 2D Side Scroller, where you almost exclusively use the mouse to move Sadwick around, talk to characters, pick up and use objects, combine objects, and bunch of other things! You also use ESC to access the Main Menu, Save/Load Screen, etc. and the Spacebar to show "Hints" (It just shows you what you can click on in the current scene.) For the most part the game controls quite well, everything is nice and fluid. By holding down the RMB (MB2) for about 1.5 seconds on an active area, a menu pops up where you can interact further with an item (You have an Eye for Looking closer at the item, a Mouth for talking or eating, and a Hand for picking an item up.) This works well as you are able to examine items in a game closely than most other games, and it's sometimes funny (or sad) to hear Sadwick's thoughts. There are a fair share of puzzles, and 4 Mini-Games (I'll get into that on the Difficulty Area) in this game. You'll get an Acheviment every-time you solve a Mini-Game, or you'll get one if you Skip them all!GRAPHICS & ART-STYLE -This game has amazing art and graphics! All of the scenes are hand-drawn and the animations are also hand-done. They look stunning and not something you see a whole lot anymore in games. One of the highest highlights of this game is its fantastic art-style! As far as Graphics go, for a game released in 2009/10 I say its aged pretty well! There are no Graphic Options (Basically what you get is what you get) and there is no Widescreen Mode and the Resolution does max out at a certain point. Somewhat disapointing since this game was released in 2010, however not a deal-breaker and something I am able to overlook. In my person opinion, I think you will not be disapointed by the way this game looks, in fact, I think you will be amazed!STORY -The story in this game is fantastic! It's very emotional at times and has amazing plot twists! Some of the most unexpected things happen during the storyline. There are a total of 4 Chapters in this game! It took me around 6 Hours to do the First Chapter since I was trying to get used to the gamplay, Chapter 2 took me around 3 hours, Chapter 3 around 2 1/2 hours, and Chapter 4 around 3 1/2 hours. Keep in mind I am usually slower at completing games. The story again is another amazing highlight of this game. I don't want to spoil anything though, so I won't go much else into this, but in my Personal Opinion I don't think you will be disapointed with the story. It is so gripping and keeps you on the edge of your seat for most of the adventure!DIFFICULTY -This game starts out pretty simple (Like most games) however it does get pretty challenging. Challenging to the point where I had the YouTube Walkthrough pulled up in case I needed it! I do consider myself an Expert at these types of games, however on some things I couldn't figure out, some made sense once I saw it and other made absolutely made no sense and you would only do it by purely guessing. Also, the Mini-Games are another story! I skipped every single one after attempting each one for about 10 minutes. There are 4 and there really isn't any "Logic" behind 3 of them. It's just guess and hope you are right. So I would mark this game down for it's poor puzzle design. Now, I don't want easy puzzles, but I don't want puzzles that are just random and don't have you show any logic to solve them. Other than the Mini-Games, there are random puzzles spread throughout the game and some can be solved by looking around at other areas again and searching through your inventory, and some (for most of you) would probably require you to look up the Walkthrough on YouTube to see how they did it. One downfall of this is the Difficulty, it's pretty brutal, however you will get thorugh it. It doesn't prevent me from reccomending this game! Like stated above, it took me around 16 Hours to complete this game for the first time. I am usually slower at completing games. For the average person I'd say it would take around 10-15 hours depending on your Skill Level.SOUNDTRACK -The Soundtrack for this is AMAZING! Some of the tracks can keep you on edge while playing while others are more mellow and relaxing to listen to. The greatest thing is this game comes with the complete soundtrack free of charge (You can find where your the Game Files are for this game > bonus > soundtrack.) It comes in .mp3 and .flac! It's $6.99 on iTunes and Amazon, and I was considering buying it until I found it in the game files (I wish they told you it came with it) so I'm telling you this now to prevent you from accidently buying it on iTunes or Amazon. Again, the Soundtrack is another reason to buy this game.ACTORS, DIALOGUE, & CHARACTERS -**NOTICE! I played this game using the English Voice Actor and English Subtitles!!**One thing most people criticized on was the Voice Actor for Sadwick in this game. Yes, I will admit it's not the best ever and he does sound whiney and depressed (which he is a "Depressed Clown" so I shouldn't be so surprised on that) however I don't think it's THAT bad. I personally think it's okay. If it absolutely bothers you, try using the German voice as I've heard that's better from other reviewers, with the English Subtitles. The Dialogue in this game is pretty good. However some of the language that they use I'm not 100% sure most 12 year olds would understand. Like I've kept saying, he is depressed, so he does hint certain things that would be suicidal at times and sometimes just down-right sad and makes you feel bad for him. Examples: "Nothing here but a Deep-Dark shaft, much like my life;" "Nothing but a deep dark abyss. Don't do it Sadwick, stay away from the edge..." Sadwick also uses the words "D*mn" and "He*l" a few times in this game. You will meet other characters throughout this game however usually you will only see them for only that Chapter and then once the chapter is over you won't see them again the rest of the game. There is one exception to that, however that would be spoiling part of the story so I will leave it out.FINAL THOUGHTS -It's an amazing game! I would totally reccomend it if you enjoy Casual or Adventure Games, enjoy 2D Side-Scroller type games, enjoy games with Emotional Stories, or enjoy Difficult Games (Again, don't let the difficulty detour you from buying the game. It's an amazing game and don't let my thoughts about the difficulty persaude you otherwise from buying it simply because of that reason...)I reccomend this game!!

												The Whispered World is a wondefully drawn game let down by lackluster voice acting, some illogical puzzles and a disappointing ending.This is a point and click adventure in the traditional sense, it doesn't really try to innovate or stray away from the genre in any way. The only thing slightly unusual is that you have a pet creature following you around, which can also transform into different forms. And that regularly comes into play when trying to solve puzzles, thank goodness too because there are a lot of fun interactions made possible by this.So what are the primary components of a traditional style point and click game? Well, that would be the story, the setting, the art, the dialogue, the voice acting and the puzzles. The parts where this game does well would be the art and the dialogue. The story and the setting show much more promise in the beginning, however as things start to unravel so does the strength of the writing.That leaves us with the voice acting and the puzzles. Except for the main protagonist I wouldn't say the voice acting is especially bad, it is merely let down by bad editing. Plenty has been said by others of the main protagonist and his annoying voice acting, perhaps it was even intentional, but it is bad design to make him so when it serves no story purpose. The puzzle design varies greatly, some puzzles are illogical and appear to exist merely to frustrate the player, while others make use of the tools presented to you in an intuitive and satisfying to solve way.There are also some UI issues that plague the game, but as it is a very minimilastic game I can overlook them.All in all, I recommend it to point & click adventure game enthusiast, however not to very many others.6½ / 10

												I've got some mixed feelings here. The Whispered World isn't the greatest point-and-click adventure game I've played, but ultimately it's a solid game that handles its story, characters, and themes really well and features acceptable, if challenging, puzzle mechanics.The best element of the game by far is its character development: specifically, the way the game develops its protagonist, Sadwick. To put it simply, Sadwick is utterly unlikeable when you begin the game. Picture a combination of Jeffery Dallas from the Julian Smith videos and Marvin the Depressed Robot from Hitchhiker's Guide--except that his complaining, self-absorbtion, and misery are all treated unironically, and not as a source of humor. He writes bad poetry about his feelings, sobs over his rotten circumstances, and loses his temper at his lovably senile grandfather. But while the game doesn't treat Sadwick's disposition mockingly, it also doesn't take him too seriously. Sadwick isn't an existential hero fighting helplessly against tragic circumstances. He's just an ornery kid with a lousy life who responds the way any self-interested person might. As the game goes on, however, Sadwick slowly and subtly transforms to the point that you are genuinely concerned with his wellbeing and with the success of his quest. Where other characters inertly accept the coming end-of-the-world scenario at the center of the game's story, Sadwick steps up and tries to change things, certain as he is at first that his actions will prove pointless. The further into the game you go, the less gloomy and caustic Sadwick becomes. And as he grows in confidence--or at least determination--he becomes a truly sympathetic character. By the game's end, I loved the little guy. The game's other characters are more of a mixed bag. Some, such as Grandpa, are quite lovable, while others, such as Bobby (the King's messenger) and Loucaux (the main villain) can be rather unlikeable or one-dimensional. The characters from the game's second section are my favorite. The sleep-deprived landowner Ruben and his loud, enthusiastic servant Bando form the perfect odd couple and are also the most objectively interesting characters in the game. One thing that can be said for the game's characters is that they all embody the story's main themes in unique and fascinating ways. Time and again, characters that occupy "important" roles in the game's world prove powerless in preventing the world's end, while little Sadwick the clown from the traveling circus does all the work. But the characters in positions of authority are always weak because they choose to be--because the game's main theme is the contrast between activity and stagnation. So Bobby is paralyzed by fear and ultimately turns over his all-important mission to Sadwick. Ruben idly obsesses over his 10,000 silver pearls and can't even enjoy the luxurious life he has made for himself. And the King, who is supposed to save the world, lies dying behind locked doors that only he can open. It's refreshing to see a story that recognizes that perfection is never static. It's not something that is whole and immaculate until it is broken, but rather something that people must actively work to maintain. The Whispered World's story and gameplay unfold in four large sections, in which Sadwick does everything he possibly can to save the world despite a prophecy (known only to him) that he will ultimately be responsible for destroying it. The episodic structure of the game has some real benefits--and some pitfalls. For one thing, it means that you wind up going to many more locations and environments than you might in the typical point-and-click adventure game. Since there's not but so much backtracking, the game stresses progress and discovery and strikes a nice balance between presenting new areas and fully exploring old ones. But since the game doesn't feature an overworld-style main area, you never feel especially grounded as you play the game. That factor, combined with the real sense of urgency in the game's plot, could make you impatient to make progress. And impatience in this game is a real killer, since some of the puzzles are dastardly hard to figure out. For the most part, the game isn't totally unintuitive--solutions usually make sense once you figure them out or look them up--but the game often doesn't provide many context clues to point you toward the proper solution to its puzzles, and certain gameplay scenarios would be near-impossible to figure out without help. I found myself checking a walkthrough almost every thirty or forty minutes, and I only rarely regretted giving up on certain puzzles. The game is darned tricky, in part because there are just so many ways to interact with the game's environments. In addition to trying out items on environmental objects and on other items, as in most point-and-click adventure games, you can also use your pet caterpillar Spot, in any of various forms you discover throughout the game, to interact with things. And some puzzles require you to use the "mouth" icon (which is primarily used for speaking with other characters) on other objects or talk with the same characters on multiple separate occasions to open up new paths. Apart from the gameplay and the story, The Whispered World features pretty good visuals. The hand-drawn backgrounds to each area are lovely and intricate, although they tend to carry somewhat of a melancholy mood. And the game's spare and lonesome music only adds to that effect. Character animations, on the other hand, tend to look unpolished and inexact, and somehow the cutscenes are even worse. The quality of the voice acting is so-so, with certain characters who are downright unlistenable, and the game ramrods lines of dialogue into each other, clipping off the first syllable of most lines and making the voices harder to listen to. Dialogue is snappy--Sadwick throws a lot of nice barbs at just about everybody he encounters--but occupies too much of the game. Conversations can go on forever, and you have to go through some of them really thoroughly to advance in the game. I mean it when I say that this game only gets better and better as it goes along. The story is great, and even the requisite big reveals at the end only add to the meaning of the game. The characters are nicely handled, the gameplay is fun when you don't get hung up for too long, and the game ultimately provides a really satisfying experience to anyone enduring enough to soldier through it.

												An undeniably charming little game, the art style is beautiful as is the soundtrack, the characters are funny and engaging, Sadwick's depressed commentary is dry and at times hilarious and the setting is lovely, especially if you like quirky folklore type fables, I mean - what's not to love about the idea of "The Tale of Sadwick the Travelling Clown"? There's a lot of meaning behind the story and The Whispered World will definitely give you some food for thought, especially if you see it through to the amazing ending. The gameplay is standard Daedalic Games Point & Click fare - combining objects, environmental puzzles, tiles, pipes, colours. It isn't groundbreaking, but it doesn't need to be - the formula works, and it works well. One thing I will say though, is that some of the puzzles are not for the uninitiated when it comes to P&C games, I definitely struggled in some areas and caved in to the temptation of Google... - I'd say this is much more suited to fans of the genre and not for new faces.Sadly, the game is let down by a myriad of little bugs... I definitely haven't had as many issues as some of the reviews on here have mentioned, but they do exist, I managed to look past them for the most part but they were a tad annoying. Overall, I did enjoy my time with The Whispered World, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it at full price. If you happen to be picking up Daedalic Bundle and it's included (like I did) then definitely play it, or if you can catch it on sale for half price then that wouldn't be too shabby either - either way, if you're a Point & Click fan, you should try and play it at some point. 												I discovered The Whispered World after beating all three Deponia titles and ending up plowing through Daedalic's game catalog. This title struck out and I decided to purchase it due to the abundance of positive reviews. I had a nice time completing The Whispering World, but I expected more. The game is mediocre at best, containing certain pros and cons that end up making for a experience that is only memorable due to it's unexpected ending. Basically, it functions as a normal point&click game, this one being set in a fantasy world full of queer creatures and interesting places to visit and explore.  The art design is a positive aspect of this title, with original scenarios and striking detail existing in them. However, the low resolution at which the game runs can lower the bar for some gamers. The achievements are easily obtainable and take, at maximum two playthroughs to complete them. Negatively, a hint system or something related would be appreciated. Countless times did I get stuck and had to look for a playthrough in order to continue the main quest. Also, the voice acting is of a poor-medium quality. Sadwick himself proves, after hours of hearing him talk, to have an annoying voice, something that can be game breaking for some. TWW does not offer any reason to replay it's main story, besides an achievement or two. The story is not good nor as it is bad. Just don't get your hopes up. The usage of Spot, Sadwick's pet, is original and distinguishes the game from other point&click titles. I did not have any problems running TWW, no crashes nor black screens. Many players report those problems, so beware of that. All and all, I do recommend The Whispering World to the average point&click gamer. content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												The Whispered World is by no means a bad game. In fact it's actually a really good game, with some exceptional faults that destroy the rest of the magic.The game is a delight to view, the hand rendered backgrounds are exceptional and even the pen and line animations are good, if slightly halting at times. The cutscenes suffer a little as they pull completely from the Disney style animation and lack the richer background texture and colour palette.The music is also a delight, and fits the fantastic world well, with soft natural tones that play quietly in the background and aren't a distraction at all. As for the voice acting, it was fairly bad. The narrator (Sadwick's voice) is nasal and annoying, to the point of being so annoying that I simply ended up turning the sound off and played by reading the subtitles. That said albeit it being annoying, the catch is the voice is a perfect one to suit the pessimistic, morose main character.Now coming to the characterisation, Daedalic seem to enjoy taking unlikable unlikely hero's and making them the protagonists (Rufus in Deponia). Sadwick continues this trend, he complains, and generally acts like a complete misanthrope, to the exasperation of not only his circus family, who deny him doing anything as he invariably messes it up  and himself. It's a difficult character to make a protagonist, as games require an active character, willing to undertake quests and action. As an unwilling character Sadwick seems "forced" and it makes him most difficult to identify with, however his lifting mood and transformation after a few success, that makes him more of an optimist alleviate this feeling, so it is worth sticking with. Spot serves as the ability extender in this game, and he is appealing not only for his unwavering dog-like faith and devotion to Sadwick, but also because you can't help wondering what creature he actually is that he can be dissected, set on fire and compressed and yet still survive. Spot is probably the games greatest mystery, and moreover his transitions between forms is amusing to watch.The rest of the characters are fairly forgettable, with uninteresting dialogue and generic set-ups that don't add anything particularly new or interesting to the game, mainly serving as clue givers to the puzzle-solving scenarios.The plot itself is short, and self-contained moves along fairly rapidly between puzzles and is otherwise well constructed, except for the dismal plot-twist ending. It is a plot-twist so generic, cliche and overused that it in fact lessens the impact of the game and delimits the otherwise more interesting philosophical underpinning to the game. It is meant to play upon your heart-strings and emotionally manipulate you, and it does achieve this, you will feel emotionally manipulated, butI still found it to be too disappointing, even though I suspected that he would "wake up and find it all a dream".The gameplay is itself not bad as far as point and click games go. The major hold up is the frustrating menu system, that slows down interactions, requiring you to click the mouse twice to look, speak or touch and a rather clunky inventory system, that doesn't support mouse scrolling. Walking about is simple enough, however every now and then the click to walk would hang and I found myself only able to click on interactive objects, precipitating a need to exit and re-enter the area. A fairly frustrating little bug.I really would be able to recommend this short adventure game, but there are better titles out there to play. So only pick this up if it's on sale, you're a Daedalic fan and must own all their titles or have played most of the other more highly recommended point n click adventures and are still looking for a fix.

Posted: September 26, 2015
												Two things initially led me to this title. Having just completed the strangely compelling Broken Age, which wistfully plunged me right back into classic adventure gaming, I was now primed for more quality point and clicking. Then I saw the excellent trailer for The Whispered World's upcoming sequel, Silence. I was sold.Some nice in-game animations and elegant background art make this game mostly enjoyable for the eyes. The carefully crafted hand-drawn environments are all of uncompromising high quality, sometimes with an air of Discworldness charm. The overall visual quality is immediately appealing.The game's most disheartening facet is unfortunately reason alone to completely soil the entire experience: Sadwick is an immeasurably insupportable lead character. His unlikeable depressed loser personality shows very few redeeming qualities and, from memory, bears no comparable equivalent in the long history of comically incompetent protagonists. However, this is still nothing compared to his especially unbearable voice. Why the developer chose to ruin an otherwise decent game with such grating performance and amateur voice direction is beyond reason.Uneven dialogue quality often turns into boring overdrawn segments and repeats unnecessarily. An annoying audio glitch cuts off the beginning of every single line, resulting in characters that appear not to take a breath in between sentences. It is not all bad - there are a few interesting characters and situations, but they get lost in the affair's global tediousness.Interactions feel dated: the player pointlessly grabs anything in sight, often without prior insight to its possible future use, and tries to combine items more or less logically to complete puzzles. Sure, that's old school adventuring, but the game does a poor job of guiding the player subtly or making you feel smart when completing objectives. Most glaring is the illogical use of Spot, the hero's inexplicably shape-shifting pet, which feels like a tacked-on solution for puzzles that otherwise make little sense.To top it off the game kept crashing several times towards the end, coupled with very buggy click registrations that gave it a sense of poor technical quality.There is no telling how much I wanted to like The Whispered World. I really did, but that feeling rapidly transformed into an eagerness to get it over with and move on to something better.

												Mediocre depressing point and click adventure game. I laughed exactly twice - and one of those was at *after* the credits had rolled.Personally I think that the story could have been more interesting (and very different) if the deus ex machina at the end of the game had been explored throughout the entire game. I kind of don't want to say what that is because the authors clearly wanted it to be a surprise, but the entire game is a metaphore that you only discover once it's finished. I could go back and play it again to see if there were any clues, but honestly - it's not worth my time.Gameplay wise it had an interesting mechanic with the pet catepillar named "Spot" being able to transform into different shapes, which is used a number of times throughout the game to solve puzzles. Some of these aren't obvious why Spot was necessary, but most of them make sense - however I felt the way you obtain new abilities after the first one is completely non-obvious and counter-intuitive, seemingly doing things that by all rights should have killed Spot.If you're looking for a good point+click adventure game, I would recommend checking out The Book of Unwritten Tales, The Raven: Legacy of a Master Thief, The Longest Journey (not to be confused with Dreamfall: The Longest Journey), Toonstruck (if you can find a copy of it somewhere), The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav and Edna and Harvey: The Breakout. If you've already played all those and are still looking for more adventure games then you might considder this one. I'd certainly play this over Deponia, but that's mostly because I couldn't stand the protagonist in Deponia.

												Overall, this was an enjoyable, unique game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys adventure games with strong dialogue and a compelling plot. The game is, however, flawed with strange bugs. For example, the game will just pop back to the menu screen randomly. You can click "return to game" and it will go back to where it crashed, but still a bug. The cut scenes are the weakest part of the game, with terribly cheap-looking animations. Even the director commentary details how they ended up outsourcing the cut scenes to save money.Despite these oddities, the game is funny, the main character Sadwick is lovable and I enjoy following him through the story. His commentary is so fresh, I literally clicked on everything I could just to hear what he would say when he touched, looked, and licked something (yes, one of the optionis a mouth, and you can "mouth" every object). The fact that he also has a lovable, strangly malleable pet catepillar is all the more enjoyable.The puzzles are pretty lame (one is even a slider puzzle...) but you can skip them. The real fun comes with the object puzzles and this awesome sequence where you control your pet Spot. The game is a little overly existential with a peculiar ending, but the game is solid and kind of a gem.

												Just finished this charming point-and-click adventure & I loved it!! I finished it in 2 nights and just under 12 hours, and did not have any issues clicking with the cursor to start my adventure. That bug seems to be fixed. :)What I loved:- The art style is gorgeous, and I loved the retro style animated cutscenes! I see that for some players this was a drawback, but not for me!! It gives the whole game a nostalgic storybook fantasy feel, which is a huge plus in my opinion. The music is also lovely, and suits the game perfectly!- I played this game with the English audio, and aside from some odd clipping in some early dialogue, I thought it was great! I see that many players are complaining that Sadwick's voice is annoying, & they suggest playing it with the German audio & English subtitles. I personally didn't find his voice irritating at all, and found all of the game's English voice work to be very quirky and reminiscent of all my favorite vintage cartoon shows. I think it is important to understand the spirit of the game (which seems to be a kind of homage to all of my favorite dated fantasy things) in order to appreciate the English audio's charm. But it is wonderful that the German language audio is an option, of course. :)- The puzzles are pretty challenging! I am usually complaining that puzzles in adventure games are a bit too easy, but this is not so in The Whispered World! The puzzle solutions are often not obvious at all, & *most* of the time I enjoyed the challenge. (will explain further below.)- The world is very quirky & charming, with lots of oddball characters who have lots of personality & provide some very strange tasks to complete! The Neverending Story/Labyrinth vibe is STRONG in this game, so if you like puzzle point-and-click adventure games and also loved those movies then you will probably love the Whispered World! :)- The story & characters were compelling. Not that I expected anything less from a Daedalic adventure, but still! :D  I was in a rush to get through the puzzles so I could see what happened next!- The ending. I did not expect the ending AT ALL. It was a pleasant surprise, and unexpectedly moving. I totally cried because I am a big softie.- I really loved the game's sense of humor as well. I laughed a lot playing this game.There is one aspect of The Whispered World however that was very irritating to me, and that is....SADWICK WALKS VERY SLOWLY!! Yes, you can double click to skip to the next area, but only as long as you can see the exit node, and many canvases were very big!! So before I could skip to the next location I would still have to wait for Sadwick to sloooowly plod along. This is especially frustrating when dealing with a challenging puzzle that has objectives all over the place. I ended up having to consult a guide a few times, which I *hate* doing, just to save me time walking from point A to point B over and over again trying to work a puzzle out so I could get on to enjoying the story!Overall though, I really enjoyed playing this game, & I absolutely recommend it! I'm playing its sequel 'Silence' next, & I can't wait!
